siteMetadata.title: Apollo GraphQL Docs
siteMetadata.description: A guide to using Apollo Server

frontmatter.title: Deploying with AWS Lambda
frontmatter.description: How to deploy Apollo Server with AWS Lambda

children.value: AWS Lambda is a service that allows users to run code without provisioning or managing servers. Cost is based on the compute time that is consumed, and there is no charge when code is not running.
This guide explains how to setup Apollo Server 2 to run on AWS Lambda using Serverless Framework. To use CDK and SST instead,
The following must be done before following this guide:
Configure the AWS CLI with user credentials
Install the serverless framework from NPM
Setting up a project to work with Lambda isn't that different from a typical NodeJS project.
Next, set up the schema's type definitions and resolvers, and pass them to the
. It's also important to note that this file must be named
, as the config example in a later step depends on the filename.
// Construct a schema, using GraphQL schema language
// Provide resolver functions for your schema fields
pay close attention to the last line

properties.ariaLabel: deploying with the serverless framework permalink

children.value: is a framework that makes deploying to services like AWS Lambda simpler.
Serverless uses a config file named
to determine what service to deploy to and where the handlers are.
For the sake of this example, the following file can just be copied and pasted into the root of your project.

# serverless.yml

service: apollo-lambda
provider:
  name: aws
  runtime: nodejs14.x
functions:
  graphql:
    # this is formatted as <FILENAME>.<HANDLER>
    handler: graphql.graphqlHandler
    events:
    - http:
        path: /
        method: post
        cors: true
    - http:
        path: /
        method: get
        cors: true
After configuring the Serverless Framework, all you have to do to deploy is run
should output something similar to this example:

> serverless deploy
Serverless: Packaging service...
Serverless: Excluding development dependencies...
Serverless: Uploading CloudFormation file to S3...
Serverless: Uploading artifacts...
Serverless: Uploading service .zip file to S3 (27.07 MB)...
Serverless: Validating template...
Serverless: Updating Stack...
Serverless: Checking Stack update progress...
..............
Serverless: Stack update finished...
Service Information
service: apollo-lambda
stage: dev
region: us-east-1
stack: apollo-lambda-dev
api keys:
  None
endpoints:
  POST - https://ujt89xxyn3.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/dev/
  GET - https://ujt89xxyn3.execute-api.us-east-1.amazonaws.com/dev/
functions:
  graphql: apollo-lambda-dev-graphql

First, it builds the functions, zips up the artifacts, and uploads the artifacts to a new S3 bucket. Then, it creates a Lambda function with those artifacts, and if successful, outputs the HTTP endpoint URLs to the console.
The resulting S3 buckets and Lambda functions can be viewed and managed after logging in to the
To find the created S3 bucket, search the listed services for S3. For this example, the bucket created by Serverless was named
To find the created Lambda function, search the listed services for
. If the list of Lambda functions is empty, or missing the newly created function, double check the region at the top right of the screen. The default region for Serverless deployments is
If you changed your mind, you can remove everything from your AWS account with
. It combines the HTTP server framework
that translates between Lambda events and Express requests. By default, this is entirely behind the scenes, but you can also provide your own express app with the
